instruction: How did the performance of Gaussian processes regression (GPR) compare to other commonly used empirical methods in estimating forest leaf area index (LAI) using airborne hyperspectral data?
Output:
The performance of Gaussian processes regression (GPR) was compared to three commonly used empirical methods, namely narrowband vegetation indices (VIs), partial least square regression (PLSR), and artificial neural network (ANN), in estimating forest leaf area index (LAI) using airborne hyperspectral data. 

The results showed that when using the entire spectral data (400-2500 nm), GPR yielded the most accurate LAI estimation, with a cross-validated coefficient of determination (R-cv(2)) of 0.67 and a root mean square error (RMSEcv) of 0.53 m(2) m(-2). In comparison, the best performing narrowband VI (SAVI2) had an R-cv(2) of 0.54 and an RMSEcv of 0.63 m(2) m(-2), PLSR had an R-cv(2) of 0.74 and an RMSEcv of 0.73 m(2) m(-2), and ANN had an R-cv(2) of 0.68 and an RMSEcv of 0.54 m(2) m(-2).

instruction: Can the potential of Gaussian processes regression (GPR) to estimate forest leaf area index (LAI) using airborne hyperspectral data be considered superior to traditional methods?
Output: Yes, the potential of Gaussian processes regression (GPR) to estimate forest leaf area index (LAI) using airborne hyperspectral data can be considered superior to traditional methods. The study compared GPR with three commonly used empirical methods, namely narrowband vegetation indices (VIs), partial least square regression (PLSR), and artificial neural network (ANN). The results showed that GPR yielded the most accurate LAI estimation compared to these traditional methods. GPR achieved a cross-validated coefficient of determination (R-cv(2)) of 0.67 and a root mean square error (RMSEcv) of 0.53 m(2) m(-2), which were better than the performance of the other methods. Additionally, when a spectral subset obtained from the analysis of VIs was used as model input, the predictive accuracies of GPR, ANN, and PLSR were generally improved, further highlighting the potential of GPR in estimating LAI. Therefore, based on these findings, GPR can be considered a superior alternative to traditional methods for estimating LAI using airborne hyperspectral data.
